lines.text: Enter HELENA and Clown

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: My mother greets me kindly is she well

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: She is not well but yet she has her health: shes very merry but yet she is not well: but thanks be given, shes very well and wants nothing i, the world but yet she is not well.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: If she be very well, what does she ail, that shes not very well

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, shes very well indeed, but for two things.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: What two things

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: One, that shes not in heaven, whither God send her quickly! the other that shes in earth, from whence God send her quickly!
Enter PAROLLES

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own good fortunes.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: You had my prayers to lead them on and to keep them on, have them still. O, my knave, how does my old lady

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would she did as you say.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, I say nothing.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Marry, you are the wiser man for many a mans tongue shakes out his masters undoing: to say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing, is to be a great part of your title which is within a very little of nothing.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Away! thourt a knave.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: You should have said, sir, before a knave thourt a knave thats, before me thourt a knave: this had been truth, sir.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Go to, thou art a witty fool I have found thee.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Did you find me in yourself, sir or were you taught to find me The search, sir, was profitable and much fool may you find in you, even to the worlds pleasure and the increase of laughter.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: A good knave, i faith, and well fed. Madam, my lord will go away tonight A very serious business calls on him. The great prerogative and rite of love, Which, as your due, time claims, he does acknowledge But puts it off to a compelld restraint Whose want, and whose delay, is strewd with sweets, Which they distil now in the curbed time, To make the coming hour oerflow with joy And pleasure drown the brim.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Whats his will else

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: That you will take your instant leave o the king And make this haste as your own good proceeding, Strengthend with what apology you think May make it probable need.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: What more commands he

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: That, having this obtaind, you presently Attend his further pleasure.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: In every thing I wait upon his will.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I shall report it so.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I pray you. Come, sirrah.
Exit PAROLLES
Exeunt
